thread.title: Battle of the rookies: Sens' Matt O'Connor starts vs. Michael Condon
thread.title_full: Battle of the rookies: Sens' Matt O'Connor starts vs. Michael Condon

title: Battle of the rookies: Sens' Matt O'Connor starts vs. Michael Condon
text:
Ottawa Senators 
Dave Cameron says his decision to give a rookie goalie his first NHL start Sunday night had nothing to do with the fact Montreal was doing the same. 
And so it was that everybody expecting to see a Craig Anderson-Carey Price showdown at Canadian Tire Centre instead had to settle for Matt O'Connor versus Michael Condon. 
"I don't make my decisions based on what the other team does," Cameron said before the Senators regular season home opener against their biggest rivals. "I don't coach them. I just make them based on what I think is best for our team." 
A highly touted free agent signed out of Boston University in the spring, the 23-year-old O'Connor is only still with the Senators NHL squad because Craig Anderson's backup, Andrew Hammond, is sidelined by a groin injury. The plan was to have O'Connor finish training camp with the big team then head to Binghamton for development. 
O'Connor was credited with two of the Senators three pre-season wins, giving up six goals on 72 shots while posting a 2.98 GAA. He was especially sharp in an exhibition appearances against Carolina in Newfoundland, where he turned aside all 18 pucks that came his way. 
After that performance, GM Bryan Murray stated he was impressed with the Sault St. Marie native and he believed O'Connor would be NHL ready early into the year. 
Nobody expected it would mean for the home opener, but Anderson, after winning games in Buffalo and a shootout against the Leafs Saturday night, was given a rest against the Habs. 
"Early in the season you always kind of gage the workload of everybody," said Cameron. "I think all the things are lined up that it's the right decision." 
Asked if he thought O'Connor had the makeup to handle the pressures of playing a home opener, Cameron cracked: "How about I tell you that after the game? 
"We think it's the right decision," he continued. "We think it's not going to affect him. There's pressure, there's always pressure. If you're going to last in this business, you better learn how to handle it. It's a real opportunity for him." 
With the Habs playing Saturday night in Boston, coach Michel Therrien decided to give Price a break and go with the 25-year-old Condon, who beat Dustin Tokarski out of the backup role with a strong training camp. The undrafted 25-year-old played his first AHL season in 2014-15 for the Habs AHL affiliate in Hamilton, where he posted a 23-19-6 record with a strong .921 save percentage. 
In 93 minutes of pre-season play for Montreal, Condon stopped all 38 shots he faced. Sponsored Links
